aboutpage.title: About Raphael Jerusalmy
aboutpage.subtitle: From intelligence officer to award‑winning novelist
aboutpage.biography: Raphael Jerusalmy was born in Montmartre in 1954. After graduating from both the École Normale Supérieure and the Sorbonne, he served fifteen years in Israeli military intelligence before turning to humanitarian work and, eventually, to the trade of rare books in Tel Aviv. Writing, however, became the through‑line of his life: since his explosive 2002 debut *Shalom Tsahal*, he has produced a body of fiction that blends erudition, moral urgency and narrative daring. :contentReference[oaicite:4]{index=4}
aboutpage.writingPhilosophy: “I write to illuminate the blind spots of history – the places where official archives fall silent and only the imagination can testify.”
aboutpage.influences: Jerusalmy cites François Villon, Stefan Zweig and modern reportage as touchstones, blending poetic risk with journalistic precision.

Shalom Tsahal.synopsis: Part memoir, part strategic essay, this debut pulls back the curtain on Israeli intelligence operations.
Shalom Tsahal.excerpt: "Intelligence is never a matter of facts alone; it is a wager on human nature."

Saving Mozart.synopsis: Otto J. Steiner, dying of tuberculosis, plots to sabotage a Nazi‑controlled Mozart festival.
Saving Mozart.excerpt: "Music, my only remaining lung, fills the cavities that disease hollowed out."

The Brotherhood of Book Hunters.synopsis: Poet‑thief François Villon is enlisted to secure a subversive Gutenberg print before it reshapes Europe.
The Brotherhood of Book Hunters.excerpt: "The scent of ink is the scent of revolt."
quotes: “An exuberant adventure novel brimming with energy, mischief and erudition.” – L’Express :contentReference[oaicite:6]{index=6}

Les obus jouaient à pigeon vole.synopsis: A lyrical reconstruction of the day Apollinaire was wounded on the Western Front.
Les obus jouaient à pigeon vole.excerpt: "Shells drew invisible calligraphy above the trench‑line."

Evacuation.synopsis: Under relentless rocket fire, Tel Aviv is abandoned – except for the children who reclaim its ruins.
Evacuation.excerpt: "In the silence after the sirens, imagination became our only architecture."

The Rose of Zaragoza.synopsis: A secret Judeo‑Christian romance blooms against the terror of the Inquisition.
The Rose of Zaragoza.excerpt: "Love, like heresy, spreads by whispered syllables."

In Absentia.synopsis: Two doomed prisoners – a Parisian art collector and a communist writer – cross paths inside the Struthof camp’s sinister ‘Jewish skeleton’ project.
In Absentia.excerpt: "Saül Bernstein inhaled art like oxygen, unaware that horror was already breathing down his neck."
quotes: “Resurrects a forgotten atrocity with relentless grace.” – Livres Hebdo :contentReference[oaicite:8]{index=8}
